key_insight: TimeLens demonstrates that simple, systematic adaptations and data-centric recipes make multimodal LLMs strong, reliable baselines for video temporal grounding, without inventing complex new architectures.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of clear, reproducible baselines and optimization recipes for adapting MLLMs to the video temporal grounding (VTG) task — i.e., localizing temporal segments in video given text queries.
method: Adapt off-the-shelf multimodal LLMs to VTG via straightforward training and prompting strategies rather than novel model design.
Systematically investigate two core dimensions (data curation/quality and training/optimization recipes) to identify what most improves VTG performance.
Provide a reproducible baseline and evaluation comparisons to surface best practices for practitioners.
impact: Provides a practical, low-effort path for researchers and engineers to obtain strong VTG performance from existing MLLMs, standardizing evaluation and accelerating follow-up work in video understanding.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: input (video + text query) → MLLM processing → temporal localization output (start/end timestamps).
Comparison bar chart: VTG performance across different data curation and training recipe variants.
Timeline visualization: example video frames with highlighted ground-truth vs predicted temporal segments.
Flowchart of recommended checklist: data preparation → prompt design → fine-tuning settings → evaluation.
paper_title: TimeLens: Rethinking Video Temporal Grounding with Multimodal LLMs
paper_authors: Jun Zhang, Teng Wang, Yuying Ge, Yixiao Ge, Xinhao Li
